Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Forgiveness, Revenge, and Social Status in Groups

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborative Research: Forgiveness, Revenge, and Social Status in Groups

This project investigates the social factors that encourage individuals to pursue either forgiveness or revenge. Vengeful behavior harms relationships and careers, and invites retaliation or legal sanctions. Forgiveness avoids these risks, but can instead make the forgiver vulnerable to exploitation. Understanding why people pursue forgiveness or revenge is an important scientific puzzle and a pressing practical concern. To answer this question, the project investigates the conditions under which forgiveness or revenge will be valued and rewarded in groups. The project contributes to understanding society by developing an explanation for how forgiving and vengeful behaviors shape individuals' social standing in groups, and testing this explanation with rigorous methods. The research combines a nationally representative survey on Americans' attitudes towards forgiveness and revenge with laboratory experiments that examines how people behave when they observe forgiving or vengeful behavior, as well as why people engage in these behaviors themselves. Given the ubiquity of conflict, the costs of revenge, and the challenges of forgiveness, the research may have a number of broader impacts. Broadly, the project speaks to conflicts around issues such as contentious politics, fan violence, and national identity. By explaining why some groups will value revenge or forgiveness, the research could help us understand why some conflicts are resolved quickly (when disputants choose forgiveness) while others spiral out of control (when disputants choose revenge). By achieving these goals, the research can help point us towards more effective conflict resolution strategies. The research also contributes to the training of graduate and undergraduate students.

Past work in understanding revenge and forgiveness focuses on micro- or macro-level factors, leading sociologists to call for greater attention to meso-level factors, such as intra and intergroup processes. Responding to this call, the project develops and tests hypotheses centered on the idea that, under certain conditions, acts of forgiveness or revenge produce group benefits, and as a result are viewed as worthy of social status -- respect, prestige, and esteem -- from group members. The project also investigates whether groups tend to view forgiveness versus revenge as relatively more status-worthy, and how groups influence individuals to engage in forgiving or vengeful behaviors. To answer these questions, the project employs a survey experiment and two behavioral lab experiments. The survey experiment (Study 1) uses a nationally representative sample of US adults to examine the conditions under which Americans view revenge or forgiveness as worthy of social status. It does so for three different social contexts: politics, sports, and national identity. The lab experiments will complement the survey experiment by using a behavioral measure of social status (Study 2) and evaluating whether individuals engage in more vengeful or forgiving behavior when their groups have a history of rewarding these behaviors with social status (Study 3). By combining nationally-representative survey data (including three conceptual replications with different social identities) with behavioral lab experiments, the design strengthens both the external and internal validity of our findings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims to better understand revenge and forgiveness. Understanding why people choose to pursue revenge or forgiveness is important for both scientific and practical reasons. Revenge can disrupt workplaces, educational settings, and interpersonal relationships. Forgiveness can improve relationships between individuals and groups, but might be interpreted as a sign of weakness.
 

To understand why people pursue revenge or forgiveness, we focus on intergroup conflict. When people perceive conflict between a group they belong to (ingroups) and a rival group (outgroups)–such as those based on nationality, sports fandom, or political affiliation–how do they respond to ingroup members who are forgiving or vengeful in response to outgroup hostility? We focus on the role of social status, or the extent to which people are respected, admired, and influential within groups. We tested whether people viewed revenge or forgiveness as the more status-worthy response to insulting behavior from an outgroup. We also examined if the status-worthiness of revenge or forgiveness varies based on whether ingroup members give group-motivated (seeking to help the group) or individually-motivated (seeking to help themselves) justifications for their behavior.

We tested these ideas in three studies. Study 1 is a nationally-representative survey of 2,116 Americans. We asked respondents to read a vignette in which an outgroup member insulted an ingroup member (groups were based on nationality, sports team fandom, or political affiliation). Respondents were randomly assigned to one of four conditions, which varied on: (1) whether the ingroup member in the vignette responded to the insult in a vengeful or forgiving way, and (2) whether the ingroup member in the vignette gave a group-motivated or individually-motivated justification for their behavior.

We found that respondents viewed the forgiving group member as more status-worthy than the vengeful group member. In addition, respondents tended to view forgiving individuals as more competent and warm, but less dominant, than vengeful individuals. Reading about a forgiving ingroup member was associated with reporting positive emotions, particularly happiness and pride, while reading about a vengeful group member was associated with reporting negative emotions, particularly shame and sadness. Respondents viewed forgiveness as morally right more often than vengefulness, most commonly explaining this judgement in terms of forgiveness preventing the escalation and diffusion of the conflict. We found few differences in social status or other outcomes by the justifications (group versus individual motivation) the ingroup member in the vignette gave for their actions. Overall, the results suggest that Americans care greatly about whether their group members engage in forgiving or vengeful behaviors, but are less concerned with their motivations for doing so.

We also conducted a pair of laboratory experiments. The surveys and laboratory experiments are complementary – while the surveys allow us to learn from a nationally representative sample of Americans, the laboratory experiments allow us to observe behavior in addition to measuring attitudes. In these experiments, study participants came to the lab and played a “mixed-motive” game, in which teams could work cooperatively or competitively for cash prizes.

In Study 2, we used this laboratory setting to investigate how people treated team members who respond to aggressive outgroup behavior in (1) a forgiving or vengeful way and (2) gave group or individually-motivated justifications for their behavior. In the lab experiment, we found that participants tended to prefer revenge to forgiveness–rewarding group members who were more vengeful. At the same time, participants rated vengeful and forgiving participants as similar in status. We found relatively few differences by group versus individual motivation, although there was some evidence that group-motivated, forgiving teammates had more influence on other group members than individually-motivated forgiving teammates.

In Study 3, we examined whether people who joined forgiving or vengeful groups–those whose members praised vengefulness and criticized forgiveness, or vice versa–behaved in more vengeful or forgiving ways when such behaviors are a source of social status. Study 3 found that people marginally responded to status rewards in groups when it comes to their game decisions, but they strongly responded to status rewards when it comes to sending messages to signal their intentions. On the whole, participants communicated more vengeful or forgiving intentions consistent with their group’s reward structure. Interestingly, these behaviors persist even when individuals incur costs to engaging in these behaviors. In contrast, when group rewards are inconsistent, individuals drastically cut back on vengeful and forgiving behaviors when it is individually costly to do so.

Intergroup conflict is an enduring problem and a key puzzle for the human sciences. Our results suggest that people care deeply about whether their members are vengeful or forgiving, that such behaviors can be a source of social status in groups, and whether groups emphasize revenge or forgiveness can vary across settings. Our results are useful for understanding how group members think and interact during conflict, potentially pointing towards improved conflict resolution strategies.
